answers.author: Thomas Christie
answers.text:
A couple of the cities I have managed have done this with good results.  It is viewed as a positive by the various board members and helps them feel a little more appreciated.  However, be prepared for possible push back from the "hateful handful" that seem to exist in all cities.  They may allege the it is a misuse of public funds.  Just be sure to get Council awareness and acceptance before hand.

answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
Hi Jessica - I don’t believe I’ve ever heard of a city/county that doesn’t provide business cards for elected officials, Board & Commission members.  The city I worked for in CA provided cards with the same phone number (that went to the supporting staff person for elected, and each B & C) and a generic email that went to a “joint box” that the supporting staff monitored.  To my knowledge is it was successful and provided elected officials and B & C members with a resource to identify themselves in the community while monitored by staff.
Pam

author: Jessica Roth
text: Our City Manager is exploring the idea of providing City business cards to members of our appointed boards, i.e. Planning Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals, Public Arts Commission, etc.  Have other cities done this?  If so, what were your experiences, positive and negative.  Thanks!
title: Business Cards - Appointed Boards
